Are you not concerned about galvanic corrosion? One trip through winter on salted roads and those aluminum to stainless steel connections holding the battery boxes into the van will start to corrode. It may not happen overnight, but they will be your weakest link and have a battery box dropping out onto the road. You should use isolation between the box mounting points and the welded brackets to this issue is reduced.
https://www.albanycountyfasteners.com/blog/stainless-steel-and-aluminum/

Using epoxy on aluminum is difficult because there is a very thin layer of corrosion that nearly instantly forms on the aluminum. You have to take extra precautions to ensure that the aluminum surface is very clean in order for the epoxy to reliably bond.

when you have steal against aluminum it causes rust issues because of galvanic . In order to understand why you shouldn't use stainless  together. Galvanic  is the transfer of electrons from one material (anode) to another (cathode).

Hey Louis
I love your project and I too have a EV VW project my self. FYI, I think you to high on the amp on the mig welder and this is why you are making a hole. I recommend you practice with some scrap metal around the same gage that your plan to work it. You can find the recommended setting on speed and amps in side the cover of the welder. Once you have the settings right, just practice a little bit before going into your project. Good luck. Alex

I know it looks like there is adequate ground clearance but that is relative to the terrain you're traversing. I don't see a lot of radical "off-grid" camping in the buses future. I have to wonder if they will fit some sort of skid plate to protect those delicate assemblies. Also, mounting directly to the chassis as such is going to subject the batteries to some unappreciated vibration and shock loads. It's not like these old buses have the supple suspension attributes of a modern Tesla. I know because I traveled extensively for years in a 1965 model in the early 70s. In the end, I sincerely hope I'm wrong :-)

Louis, this is a great project, I love it, but you are very lucky so far not having a serious injury. You MUST research safety measures for using the tools you are using.

The table saw without a guide after the blade is a serious risk of kickback. Cutting metal plates like that is a serious risk of having it flying in your direction at 100km/h and seriously injuring you, specially if you stand directly behind the blade.

Welding, grinding and cutting without proper clothes is just wreck less.

If you don’t care for yourself you should at least warn viewers in the beginning of each video that you are NOT following basic safety rules.

Interesting thing about embedded metal shavings. When getting an MRI for a broken bone or illness, possibly years later, the extreme magnetism literally rips the shavings out of your skin and muscles. Even the aluminum shavings. So, you won't regret recklessness just once. Its a gift that keeps on giving. If you have any shavings embedded in your eyes from not wearing a face shield, it yanks them out also. Good luck on your project.

@Alan Mears I knew someone would ask that. Aluminum is not a ferrous metal. But, it is very conductive and in a moving magnetic field it generates an electrical field which is magnetic. There are a number of videos on YouTube demonstrating the Lenz Effect: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O9DaKP2PhL4
